column1: Sartell is a city in Benton and Stearns counties in the state of Minnesota that straddles both sides of the Mississippi River. It is part of the St. Cloud Metropolitan Statistical Area. The population was 15
column2: 876 at the 2010 census and 18
column3: 926 according to 2019 estimates
column4: making it St. Cloud's most populous suburb and fourth largest city in the central Minnesota region after St. Cloud

column1: The first known Native American tribe in the area now known as Sartell were the Dakota. Greysolon du Luht ('Duluth') visited the large Mdewakantonwan village Izatys up on Mille Lacs Lake in 1679.
As the Anishinaabe people moved westward around Lake Superior and into the interior away from the Europeans in the 18th century (1736 to about 1780)
column2: they pushed the neighboring Sioux/Dakota people to their west—in present-day Minnesota—farther south and west away from them. By 1820 the Chippewa/Anishinaabe controlled all of northern Minnesota
column3: but raids between them and the Dakota to the south continued.  This area later named Sartell was an intertribal no man's land when European French fur-traders and British geographers first descended the Mississippi River from the Anishinaabe north (Jean-Baptiste Perrault 1789
column5: and American explorers ascended the river from the Sioux south (Zebulon Pike 1805

column1: The Watab Creek in Sartell marked part of the border line between the Anishinaabe to the north and the Dakota to the south who had lived farther north and east prior to the westward migrations of the Anishinaabe. This border was legally established by the US in its 1825 Treaty with the tribes at Prairie du Chien which established a demarcation line between "the Sioux and the Chippewas' "the mouth of the first river which enters the Mississippi on its west side above the mouth of Sac (Sauk) river; thence ascending the said river (above the mouth of Sac river)".

column3: 300 Ho-Chunk people were moved to the Sartell area
column4: followed by the Chippewa/Anishinaabe sale of the area north of the Watab River and west of the Mississippi to the USA. In 1848 more members of the Ho-Chunk/Winnebago tribe (related Dakotan speakers) were moved by order of the U.S. government to the mouth of the Watab Creek
column5: now called the Long Prairie reservation
column6: to serve as a human buffer between the warring Dakota and Anishinaabe. Unhappy living between two warring tribes
column7: the Ho-Chunk lasted less than five years there when some moved again in 1853 to more peaceful territory 50 miles south on the Mississippi
column8: and three years later sold their grist and saw mills and moved south of Mankato.  A 100-yard section of the old "Indian Trail" still remains just north of the creek's mouth albeit overgrown. The area was known as 'Winnebago' at the time of the 1866 ribbon map of the Mississippi river.

column1: Sartell got its start as a small American town on the Mississippi River with lumber and a paper company as its main industries. The present site of the city was originally dubbed "The Third Rapids"
column2: as it was the third set of rough waters that French fur traders encountered as they traveled north from Saint Anthony Falls in Minneapolis.

column1: One of the first white people to settle in the fledgling town was Joseph B. Sartell
column2: who arrived in 1854 and worked as a millwright at a local sawmill. In 1877
column3: he opened a flour mill at the nearby Watab River
column4: and in 1884 he started the Sartell Brothers Lumber Company with his sons.

column2: construction began on both the Sartell Pulp and Paper Company and the Sartell Dam across the Mississippi
column3: near the "third rapids". Both were completed in 1907
column4: the dam project having claimed the lives of seven workers. Watab Pulp and Paper was rebuilt and expanded through the years
column5: passing through multiple ownerships and eventually emerging as Verso Paper's Sartell mill

column2: residents of the town decided to incorporate. Several influential people felt the town ought to be named Wengert
column3: after a local businessman. But because of Joseph Sartell's many relatives and generous contributions to the community
column4: the town was incorporated as "The Village of Sartell" in his honor. From 1907 until 1973 there was a Sartell on nearly every City Council
column5: the most prominent being Ripley 'Rip' B. Sartell
column6: store owner and mayor for 31 years.

column1: The town continued to grow slowly
column2: developing a number of businesses and a downtown on the east side of the Mississippi along U.S. Highway 10. In the 1960s
column3: the highway was rerouted
column4: greatly contributing to the demise of the downtown area. The later construction of the current Sartell Bridge over the Mississippi in the early 1980s replaced the remaining businesses. This and Sartell's location near St. Cloud's major retail center account for its lack of a traditional "downtown".

column2: Sartell-St. Stephen
column3: was created in 1969 because residents wanted to educate their children locally. Despite the lack of a downtown
column4: the city continued to grow at an increasing pace in the 1970s. From 1960 to the present
column5: the city's population has gone from 700 to over 18000.From 1979 to 1990 the mayor of the city was Robert Clinton Bogard
column6: the former owner of a ready-mix concrete company. His tenure included the expansion of Verso Paper's Sartell mill (which merged with Champion International in 1984) and DeZurik Valve Company
column7: as well as the building of the current Sartell Bridge.

column1: Sartell's largest employers have been the paper mill that started in 1907 as Watab Pulp & Paper
column2: became St. Regis Paper Company in 1947
column3: and lastly as Verso Paper Sartell Mill
column5: whose valve production plant is located in Sartell. The city also hosts a number of small businesses
column9: and salons. In 2012 the Verso Paper mill was severely damaged by an explosion and
column10: due also to decreasing paper demand
column11: was shut down and sold for parts. More recently the city has begun to urbanize
column12: adding larger chain businesses such as Walmart and Sam's Club in a newly developed area eventually to be the new downtown.

column1: Sartell's city council consists of a mayor and four members elected at large. Sartell's mayor is Ryan Fitzthum
column2: and the council members are Brady Andel
column3: Mike Chisum
column5: and Jeff Kolb. They possess the authority to pass and enforce ordinances
column8: and manage the city's financial operations
column11: and transacting other city business as required by law. The City Council also appoints a City Administrator
column12: who oversees the daily operation of the city and implements the policies of the council.City recreational facilities include 24 parks
column19: a golf course and a wading pool.

column1: The Sartell family was largely Presbyterian
column2: and helped organize the first church in the town
column3: Riverside Presbyterian
column4: on the west bank of the Mississippi River and approximately one mile north of the town's (then) sole stop-sign
column5: to serve the Sunday interests of local Protestants. Saint Francis Xavier Church
column9: a Slovenian missionary to Native Americans in the area
column10: and largely responsible for attracting the large population of Slovenian
column13: Slovakian and especially German farmers to the area and their annual bouja stand.

column1: Transportation to and from Sartell is limited to surface roads
column2: mainly U.S. Highway 10 and Minnesota State Highway 15
column3: both of which pass along the outskirts of the city. St. Cloud Metro Bus service runs to destinations in Sartell and neighboring Sauk Rapids and St. Cloud. A rail line passes through town but serves the city only as freight transportation for the Verso Sartell Paper Mill.

column1: The city's proximity to St. Cloud allows for convenient access to St. Cloud Regional Airport
column2: as well as the city's Amtrak and Greyhound stations.

column1: The dams along the Mississippi River and the waterway's relatively shallow depth render it useless for anything more than recreational watercraft traffic. Sartell's location on the river facilitated the construction of the Old Sartell Bridge in 1914
column2: which was replaced by the current Sartell Bridge in 1984.

column1: According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the city has a total area of 10.05 square miles (26.03 km2); 9.80 square miles (25.38 km2) is land and 0.25 square miles (0.65 km2) is water.U.S. Highway 10
column3: Minnesota State Highway 15
column4: and County 1 are three of the main routes in Sartell. Other nearby routes in the St. Cloud area include Interstate 94/U.S. Highway 52
column6: and County 75. Sartell is immediately north of the city of St. Cloud.

column1: The city is situated on the Mississippi River with the surrounding undeveloped property composed mainly of woodlands and farmland.
